comments.commentBody:
So, the Progressive's (liberal Democrats') approach is to ration care...even as several studies have already shown better results and less surrounding tissue damage.
Your smearing of the GOP with an assault which is false is duly noted. Medicare is already unsustainable financially, and pays doctors so little that at least 30% (including my FP of 25 years) can no longer afford to see Medicare patients, as reimbursement is below overhead costs for the doctor. A comparison with which most of us can relate would have "Gasicare" paying gas station owners 85 cents per gallon. That's what is currently being done. And you, with no apparent expert knowledge, want negotiations for lower prices.
Ever higher costs to seniors is indeed the way of Medicare. Check out he premiums proposed for 2014 and beyond.
"Comparative effectiveness" is pursued by the medical community every day, with articles, meetings, university medical center discussions. I have seen nothing that would give credit to anything done by the 2009 law.

For KS
Where did you get the figure that 30% of physicians will not take Medficare? It conflicts with real data from MedPac.

I'd like to know how much your FP made last year before I begin to shed any tears for him.

What do you make of the data that Medicare is more efficient than private insurers companies in both overhead and cost control/ http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/ezra-klein/post/competition-hasnt-wo...

If the medical community is pursuing "comparable effectiveness" how do explain the posting or the insistance of urologists on routine PSA testing when all the data show this does no goOd and may even be harmful?

This is a great example of the progressive approach to how the long term Medicare deficit should be addressed. The GOP response is to abolish Medicare and replace it with inadequate vouchers that seniors would have to use to try to purchase insurance in the marketplace. All that approach does is shift costs to individuals and ration care away from people who cannot afford it.

The progressive approach is to instead pursue the massive amounts of savings available in the system that could be achieved without reducing care. Requiring expensive new treatments, devices, and drugs to prove their value in comparison to cheaper traditional options through comparative effectiveness research (which was funded as part of the 2009 stimulus legislation) and a strengthened Independent Payment Advisory Board (which President Obama has proposed but which Congress hasn't agreed to). Two other areas for savings are allowing Medicare and other government providers to use their market power to negotiate for lower prices, and to expand Medicare to cover more people, as Medicare is far more cost effective than private insurance.

In my view, rationalizing health care spending is a far better option than shifting ever higher costs to seniors and rationing care away from those who cannot afford it.

http://www.winningprogressive.org

https://www.facebook.com/pages/Winning-Progressive/195682780442236

I'm sorry Stu but we have a country to run, not a drama class to teach.   Keep your heartbeat and your unemployment and your weak economy. I'll take the man that has proven to be fiscally responsible, who can create jobs and will give more Americans an opportunity to truly pursue the American dream. The great experiment of "let's put a college professor, with no experience and no economic skill set" in charge of the most powerful nation in the world" has proven to be as reckless as the initial concept.

So perhaps those of us who've been disappointed with Pres. Obama's  failure to stand up to the Tea Party neanderthals should vote for Willard come November and assume (pray?) that he'll turn out to be the pragmatic moderate America is looking for.  And perhaps we'll end up with universal health care after all. And perhaps American women will retain control over their own uteruses.  And perhaps gays will not have to worry about constitutional amendments denying their civil rights.  And perhaps we won't really see government benefits and services slashed to the bone and our environment permanently polluted in order to make life (even) easier for Willard and his fellow CEO's-  oops, job creators.  Well, that may just be a few too many maybes for folks like me to rely upon.  I think I'll just stick with the guy we've got (the one who at least has a heart beating inside his chest) and lay my own hopes on seeing a few of those aformentioned neanderthals get voted out of office in favor of a few sentient human beings who might actually provide the President with a small measure of support.  And then watch Willard warm up for his inevitable 2016 match-up against Andrew Cuomo.

The first 30 minutes and last 30 minutes are probably the times of greatest pilot workload, but what might happen?

Your iPhone, Kindle, or whatever isn't transmitting on a frequency anywhere close to the frequencies of other aircraft's transponders, or the navigation radios, or the GPS receivers, or the communication radios. Except for the GPS, those are all on frequencies just above those received by your car's FM radio. Your phone and digital devices might transmit as low as 800 MHz, but are more likely transmitting between 1700 and 2400 MHz, so they're nowhere close to aviation frequencies, around 120 MHz.

Given the inverse square law, your device would never be close enough to the plane's various antennae to desensitize the transceivers and receivers anyway.

So, even IF your device WERE to interfere, what might happen? The flight displays in the cockpit would be far more likely to display a receiving error than to display incorrect information (such as the plane's altitude). The plane also carries redundant instruments and systems.

I could possibly see a problem if there were limited visibility, the plane was descending on final, and one of these critical instruments failed, but that would likely result in a missed approach, not a crash.

Besides, even with fully-functional instruments, the pilots have to be able to see the runway several hundred feet before they land. If they can't they're legally required to abort the landing.

This is all much ado about nothing.

"After all, a creature without passionate conviction doesn’t cling to extremes. He surveys the scenery and makes sure his outfit doesn’t clash."

This is a perfect description of Barak Obama. He is all ambition and will do whatever to win the Presedency. Given that he is without passionate convictions he can be whatever to whomever and thereby win the vote. He is for me the perfect definition of an unvirtuous man, a man who Thomas Jefferson said was "the fit tool for the designs of ambition." And that is a grave concern. Will he do whatever powerful men want of him in order to become president and remain president or will he do what is best for the country?

I don't trust him. I won't vote for him.

That was easy. Thanks.

RC:  this column is about Mitt Romney, not Barak Obama.  You have added nothing to the conversation.  It is a useless debate strategy to say simply say "yea, he does it."  Are you disagreeing with Bruni and me that Mitt Romney lacks virtue?  If so, you need to supply evidence.  That President Obama is unvirtuous is irrelevant to this conversation.

"After all, a creature without passionate conviction doesn’t cling to extremes. He surveys the scenery and makes sure his outfit doesn’t clash."

This is a perfect description of Mitt Romney. He is all ambition and will do whatever to win the Republican nomination. Given that he is without passionate convictions he can be whatever to whomever and thereby win the vote. He is for me the perfect definition of an unvirtuous man, a man who Thomas Jefferson said was "the fit tool for the designs of ambition." And that is a grave concern. Will he do whatever powerful men want of him in order to become president and remain president or will he do what is best for the country?

I don't trust him. I won't vote for him.

Exactly. Every single piece of equipment on a plane is built to withstand interference - it's why an LCD monitor for a cockpit costs $70,000. Did you ever see the Mythbusters episode where they emulated thousands of simultaneous cell phone calls while inside a (grounded) corporate jet? Any interference in the cockpit? Nope. None: http://kwc.org/mythbusters/2006/04/episode_49_cellphones_on_plane.html
Their answer is simple: there's no way to test all of the new gadgets coming out, so they ban them all. This will change in time - they just have to coordinate with the FCC who does all of the testing.

Those running the ads in the media are, as Rita points out, complicit in speading the rot.  They profit from it so one must assume they have every interest in it continuing.  It's rather hard to take the Times editors serious when they stand to make so much money this campaign season from all the nonsense.  Still, negative ads only work if voters listen to them.  The first amendment gives candidates the right to speak and spend freely.  No one says I have to listen.

Is there any reason why newspapers, radios and tis that run the ads paid for by these PACS can't provide the identification of the key donors when the ads run?   For example:  "Paid for by the XYZ PAC, main contributors are friends of Romney".  Disclosure won't prevent the rot but at least people will know who is paying for the rot.

I respectfully disagree with Paul here and agree with Larry. There is a maturing audience of Americans who have played loads of soccer growing up and are prime for being brought back into the fold as fans (on top of the already growing fanbases). With regards to the foul described below, if you watch English soccer it isn't a red unless it's the last man back, a cleats high tackle, an elbow to the face, or a tackle from behind. On the Beckham foul there was no intent to injure and the tackle was from the side (though shielded). It was just a professional taking a yellow to stop the momentum of an attack. Just because American soccer can be physical does not make it illegitimate. What we really need to eliminate is the endless long balls and blind clears from the defense. Just as NFL teams don't throw hail mary's, MLS teams should not waste possession with rarely productive long balls. This is what made the Red Bulls' early season play so promising and demise so disappointing.

'The takeaway from the speech? Romney good. America great. Obama bad. America in trouble.'

WHH, I'm guessing you're kidding about George & "I, Me, Mine," but for those too young to know, he was the one who led the Beatles to India, and he was a lifelong meditator. I found this (at sing365.com; can't get the long URL):

"The set of pronouns which forms the song's title is a conventional way of referring to the ego in a Hindu context. For example, the Bhagavad Gita 2:71-72 can be translated as 'They are forever free who renounce all selfish desires and break away from the ego-cage of "I", "me" and "mine" to be united with the Lord.'"

So he's singing about the*trap* of self-centeredness, perhaps especially in the context of what was happening with the band. The boys sure don't look happy on that rooftop; they were to break up soon thereafter if I remember correctly.

2D, I, ME, MINE, Beatle George, must have been a tad self-centered, ya think?
BARDOT, Now there was a real live DAHL, that ANISTON, couldn't hold a candle to!
Seldom do we find 12D's full name in our XWDP's!
If you want to SELASSIE, you can catch him on TV Land!

WHH
The Gilbride complaints are without merit... as they've always been since the SuperBowl year.

Wayne Weaver is the outgoing owner of the Jaguars. His recollections on Coughlin confuse this piece. Schottenheimer is interviewing for the job with the new ownership. I hope he gets the job. Maybe Schottenheimer gets the job, and hires away Kevin Gilbride. I really hope that happens.

Truman had a sign on his desk that said "The Buck Stops Here."
In Jet's Land "The Buck Stops with Ryan".
Ryan, be a man and retire.
Johnson, be an owner and fire him.
Either way the "buck" has stopped where it should.
He was gracious as a Jet, but he was only here because he couldn't agree with Miami on his value at the time. He has been a great ambassador to the game. Thank you, Jason Taylor!

Keep Coughlin. He is smart, has authority, knows the team, gets respect, sticks to his principles (benching Bradshaw fir a half).
Keep Gilbride. He, Eli, and the receiving corps have done great.
Keep an eye out for a running back this off season.
Keep Fewell. His now healthy defense is playing as it could have these past two months.
The giants are not run by the media. They are run from up top.
The Mara's and Tishces are honorable men.
They will see that they have a TEAM that is worth keeping, with small personnel adjustments.
Jets are the exact opposite.
Fire Ryan and his staff. Bring in a no-nonsense guy like Cowher.Make a football team out of those guys.

The problem is that the $15-$20 per hour skilled labor is fast becoming the norm and with wages at those levels they do not have the means to pay taxes that will ensure a defined pension benefit plan, particularly one that ensures that the annuity payout is close to base pay, if not more.

People need to do their research before commenting on a topic they are unprepared to show factual evidence behind their opinions. To the people that say College Football players should not recieve Scholarships are ridiculous. Unless society completely changes and all of society revamps itself, this game will continue to be the foundation of a University and a great base for academic reputation. Just as much as one might love to go a concert, broadway play, movie there is a theory called the Super Star Theory. No one wants to see you play football, but they want to see the greatest athlete play and perform. These are peformers given a gift to peform at the highest level possible. Whether it adds value to society is unimportant, it is the sheer fact that people will watch and they get to recieve an education and better themselves and thus helping society.

Stunning opening to the film and stunning finale. Von Trier uses visual language like no other filmmaker, and the film moves at a glacial pace b/c every shot, every edit, is laden with "baggage", aka subtext. I don't always respond to his choice of subject matter--he's a bit schlocky and melodramatic at his core--but it's for a good cause (showing the hypocrisy and blindness of people) and as far as his technique, he is an utterly unique filmmaker--frustrating, menacing, challenging. And he has bad news for us: the universe is a cold, indifferent place and we die alone, not toasting our bourgeois status with a glass of wine, and seeking affirmation for our lifestyle in the face of death. No, no, not gonna happen. This film is a big old planet of agnostic rage squashing the calcified genres of Planet Mainstream.
